clinical_study.brief_title: Pharmacogenomics and Effective Treatment With Clopidogrel
clinical_study.official_title: Can Pharmacogenomic Testing Improve Response and Avoid Adverse Effects With Clopidogrel Therapy? A Biospecimen Bank for Genetic and Genomic Investigation of Clopidogrel.

lead_sponsor.agency: Avera McKennan Hospital & University Health Center

collaborator.agency: Avera Heart Hospital of South Dakota

clinical_study.source: Avera McKennan Hospital & University Health Center

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this biospecimen repository is to evaluate an individual's genotype, identify the variances, and understand how they relate to treatment with clopidogrel.

detailed_description.textblock: The objective of this project is to distinguish genetic profiles that will assist a practitioner in determining the right dose or alternate medication for the patient. In partnership with the genetics team of the Avera Institute for Human Genetics and physicians with the Avera Heart Hospital of South Dakota and North Central Heart Institute, the research team will perform genetic analysis to identify genetic variances.

arm_group.description: Patients taking or prescribed clopidogrel or under consideration Utilizing pharmacogenomics to determine the most effective treatment

intervention.description: Utilizing pharmacogenomics to determine the most effective treatment

study_pop.textblock: Patients of either the Avera Heart Hospital of South Dakota or North Central Heart Institute who have been precribed Clopidogrel or are being considered for treatment with Clopidogrel.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Currently taking or prescribed Clopidogrel or under consideration
- Acute/interventionPatients of the Avera Heart Hospital
- Cardiology clinic patients with the Avera Heart Hospital and North Central Heart Institute
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unable to provide informed consent
